4210000 2559000 <div> <div style="margin-left:0pt;margin-right:0pt;"> <p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12pt;border-bottom:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-weight:bold;font-size:10pt;">8</font><font style="display: inline;font-weight:bold;font-size:10pt;">. DERIVATIVE FINANCIAL INSTRUMENTS </font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12pt;border-top:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-bottom:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">We transact business in various foreign countries and are therefore exposed to foreign currency exchange rate risk inherent in revenues, costs, and monetary assets and liabilities denominated in non-functional currencies. We have entered into foreign currency exchange forward contract</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">s</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;"> and currency swap derivative instruments to selectively protect against volatility in the value of non-functional currency denominated monetary assets and liabilities, and of future cash flows caused by changes in foreign currency exchange rates. We do not designate these derivative instruments as hedging instruments under the accounting standards for derivatives and hedging. Accordingly, these instruments are recorded at fair value as a derivative asset or liability on the balance sheet with their corresponding change in fair value rec</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">ognized in &#x2018;Forei</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">gn currency transaction </font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">losses, net&#x2019; in our condensed consolidated statements of income. For purposes of the condensed consolidated statement</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">s</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;"> of cash flows, we classify the cash flows at settlement from undesignated instruments in the same category as the cash flows from the related hedged items, generally within &#x2018;Cash provided by (used in) operating activities&#x2019;. See</font><font style="display: inline;font-style:italic;font-size:10pt;"> Note 7</font><font style="display: inline;font-style:italic;font-size:10pt;"> &#x2013; Fair Value Measurements</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;"> for further details regarding the fair values of the corresponding derivative assets and liab</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">ilities.</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;"> As of June 30</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">, 2014, we did not have derivative assets or liabilities on our condensed consolidated balance sheets as all derivative forward contrac</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">ts described in the table below were en</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">tered into on June 30</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">, 2014.</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt;border-top:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-bottom:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">The following table summarizes the notional amounts of the outstanding foreign currency exchange contracts at </font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">June 30, 2014 and December 31, 2013</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">. The notional amounts of the derivative financial instruments shown below are denominated in their U</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">nited States (&#x201C;U.S.&#x201D;) D</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">ollar equivalents and represent the amount of all contracts of the foreign currency specified. These notional values do not necessarily rep</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">resent amounts exchanged by the parties and, therefore, are not a direct measure of our exposure to the foreign currency exchange risks.</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt;border-top:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 1pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-size:1pt;">&nbsp;</font> net</font></p> </td> </tr> </table></div> <p style="margin:0pt;line-height:normal;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;">&nbsp;</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-family:Times;">The account 'Foreign currency transaction losses, net' on the condensed consolidated statements of income includes both realized and unrealized gains/losses from underlying foreign currency activity and derivative contracts. These gains and losses are reported on a net basi</font><font style="display: inline;font-family:Times;">s. </font><font style="display: inline;">For the three and six months ended June 30, 2014, the net losses recognized of </font><font style="display: inline;">$0</font><font style="display: inline;">.2 million and $3.0 million, respectively, recorded on the condensed consolidated statements of income is comprised of net losses </font><font style="display: inline;">noted in the table above </font><font style="display: inline;">of </font><font style="display: inline;">$</font><font style="display: inline;">3.4 million and $5.2 million, respectively, associated with our derivative instruments partially offset by net gains of </font><font style="display: inline;">$3.2</font><font style="display: inline;"> million and </font><font style="display: inline;">$2.2</font><font style="display: inline;"> million, respectively, associated with exposure from day-to-day business transactions in various foreign currencies.</font><font style="display: inline;">&nbsp;</font><font style="display: inline;">For the three and six months ended June 30, 2013, </font><font style="display: inline;">the net </font><font style="display: inline;">losses recognized of $0.8 million and $3.4 million, respectively, recorded on the condensed consolidated statements of income is comprised of net losses </font><font style="display: inline;">$1.5</font><font style="display: inline;"> million and </font><font style="display: inline;">$14.1</font><font style="display: inline;"> million, respectively, associated with exposure from day-to-day business transactions in various foreign currencies partially offset by net gains</font><font style="display: inline;"> noted with our derivative instruments</font><font style="display: inline;">.</font> </p> <p><font size="1"> </font></p> </div> </div> <div> <div style="margin-left:0pt;margin-right:0pt;"> <p 12pt;font-family:Times New Roman;;font-size: 10pt"><font style="display: inline;font-weight:bold;"></font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-weight:bold;">10</font><font style="display: inline;font-weight:bold;">. STOCK-BASED COMPENSATION</font> </p> <p style="margin:6pt 0pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;">Stock-based compensation expense is recognized on a straight-line basis over the applicable vesting period. and $</font><font style="display: inline;">4.</font><font style="display: inline;">0</font><font style="display: inline;"> million, respectively, of stock-based compensation expense, of which </font><font style="display: inline;">$0.1</font><font style="display: inline;"> million and </font><font style="display: inline;">$0.0</font><font style="display: inline;"> million, respectively, related to the implementation of our ERP system</font><font style="display: inline;">,</font><font style="display: inline;"> was capitalized to intangible assets</font><font style="display: inline;"> on the condensed consolidated balance sheets</font><font style="display: inline;">.</font><font style="display: inline;"> During the six months ended June 30, 2014 and 20</font><font style="display: inline;">$0.2</font><font style="display: inline;"> million and </font><font style="display: inline;">$0.0</font><font style="display: inline;"> million,</font><font style="display: inline;"> respec</font><font style="display: inline;">tively, related to the implementation of our ERP system</font><font style="display: inline;">,</font><font style="display: inline;"> was capitalized to intangible assets on t</font><font style="display: inline;">he condensed consolidated balance sheets</font><font style="display: inline;">.</font> </p> <p style="margin:12pt 0pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-weight:bold;font-style:italic;">Stock Options</font> </p> <p style="margin:12pt 0pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;">Options granted generally vest over four years with the first year vesting on a cliff basis followed by monthly vesting for the remaining three years.</font> </p> <p inline;">and six </font><font style="display: inline;">months ended </font><font style="display: inline;">June 30, 2014 and 2013</font><font style="display: inline;">:</font> </p> <p ;border-right:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;background-color: #CCEEFF;height:12.75pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10pt;text-align:right;" nowrap="nowrap"><div style="float:left"></div>13.42&nbsp; </td> </tr> </table></div> <p style="margin:0pt;line-height:normal;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;">&nbsp;</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt;border-bottom:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-weight:bold;font-style:italic;font-size:10pt;">Restricted Stock Awards and Units</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt;border-top:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-bottom:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">&nbsp;</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt;border-top:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-bottom:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">From time to time, we grant </font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">restricted stock awards (&#x201C;RSA&#x201D;) and restricted stock units (&#x201C;RSU&#x201D;)</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;"> to our </font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">employees. R</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">SAs and RSUs </font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">generally vest over three or four years depending on the terms of the grant.</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">&nbsp;</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">Unvested RSAs have the same rights as those of common shares including voting rights and non-forfeitable dividend rights. However, ownership of unvested RSAs cannot be transferred until they are ve</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">sted. An unvested RSU is a contractual right to receive a share of common stock only upon its vesting. RSUs have dividend equivalent rights which accrue over the term of the award and are paid if and when the RSUs vest, but they have no voting rights.</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt;border-top:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-bottom:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">&nbsp;</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt;border-top:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-bottom:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-family:Times;font-size:10pt;">We typically grant time-based RSUs and performance-based RSUs. Time-based RSUs are typically granted on an annual basis to certain non-executive employees and vest in three annual installments on a straight-line basis beginning one year after the grant date. During the three months ended June 30, 2014 and 2013, the board of directors did not approve the grant of a material amount of</font><font style="display: inline;font-family:Times;font-size:10pt;"> time-based RSUs to non-executives. </font><font style="display: inline;font-family:Times;font-size:10pt;">D</font><font style="display: inline;font-family:Times;font-size:10pt;">uring the six months ended June 30, 2014 and 2013, the board of dire</font><font style="display: inline;font-family:Times;font-size:10pt;">ctors approved </font><font style="display: inline;font-family:Times;font-size:10pt;">0.3</font><font style="display: inline;font-family:Times;font-size:10pt;">&nbsp;million </font><font style="display: inline;font-family:Times;font-size:10pt;">grants of time-based</font><font style="display: inline;font-family:Times;font-size:10pt;"> RSU</font><font style="display: inline;font-family:Times;font-size:10pt;">s to non-executives</font><font style="display: inline;font-family:Times;font-size:10pt;">. &nbsp;</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt;border-top:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-bottom:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-family:Times;font-size:10pt;">&nbsp;</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt;border-top:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-bottom:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-family:Times;font-size:10pt;">Performance-based RSUs are typically grante</font><font style="display: inline;font-family:Times;font-size:10pt;">d on an annual basis to </font><font style="display: inline;font-family:Times;font-size:10pt;">executive</font><font style="display: inline;font-family:Times;font-size:10pt;">s</font><font style="display: inline;font-family:Times;font-size:10pt;"> and consist of a time-based a</font><font style="display: inline;font-family:Times;font-size:10pt;">nd performance-based component. </font><font style="display: inline;font-family:Times;font-size:10pt;">Dur</font><font style="display: inline;font-family:Times;font-size:10pt;">ing </font><font style="display: inline;font-family:Times;font-size:10pt;">the three months ended June 30</font><font style="display: inline;font-family:Times;font-size:10pt;">, 201</font><font style="display: inline;font-family:Times;font-size:10pt;">4 and 2013, the board of directors </font><font style="display: inline;font-family:Times;font-size:10pt;">did not approve any grants of </font><font style="display: inline;font-family:Times;font-size:10pt;">RSU</font><font style="display: inline;font-family:Times;font-size:10pt;">s to executives as part of a performance incentive program. </font><font style="display: inline;font-family:Times;font-size:10pt;">Dur</font><font style="display: inline;font-family:Times;font-size:10pt;">ing the six months ended June 30, 201</font><font style="display: inline;font-family:Times;font-size:10pt;">4 and 2013, the board of directors approved the grant of an aggregate of </font><font style="display: inline;font-family:Times;font-size:10pt;">1.0</font><font style="display: inline;font-family:Times;font-size:10pt;">&nbsp;million</font><font style="display: inline;font-family:Times;font-size:10pt;"> and </font><font style="display: inline;font-family:Times;font-size:10pt;">0.7</font><font style="display: inline;font-family:Times;font-size:10pt;"> million, respectively, </font><font style="display: inline;font-family:Times;font-size:10pt;">of RSU</font><font style="display: inline;font-family:Times;font-size:10pt;">s to executives as part of a performance incentive program. </font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt;border-top:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-bottom:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-family:Times;font-size:10pt;">&nbsp;</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt;border-top:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-bottom:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">During the three months ended June&nbsp;30, 2014 and 2013, we record</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">ed </font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">$2.8</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;"> million and </font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">$3.0</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;"> million, respectively, of stock-based </font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">compensation</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;"> expense related to RSUs. During the six months ended June&nbsp;30, 2014 and 2013, we recorded </font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">$6.5</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;"> million an</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">d &nbsp;</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">$6.0</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;"> million</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">, resp</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">ectively, of stock-based compensation expense related to RSUs. </font><font style="display: inline;font-family:Times;font-size:10pt;">The following represents the vesting schedule of performance-based RSUs granted in 2014: </font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt;border-top:1pt none #D9D9D9 align="center" style="border-collapse:collapse;margin-left:5.4pt;"> <tr> <td valign="middle" style="width:122.40pt;border-top:1pt solid #000000 ;border-left:1pt solid #000000 ;border-bottom:1pt solid the target number of RSUs based on the level of achievement of the performance goal.</font></p> </td> <td valign="top" style="width:110.20pt;border-top:1pt solid #000000 ;border-left:1pt solid #000000 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;">$</font></p> </td> <td valign="bottom" style="width:08.48%;border-top:1pt solid #000000 ;border-left:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-bottom:2pt double #000000 </tr> </table></div><hr style="border-bottom-style:solid;width:47%;height:.85pt; ;color:#000000" align="left"></hr> <div style="width:100%"><table style="width:100%;" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0"><tr><td style="width:0pt;"><p style="width:0pt;font-size:0pt;"></p></td><td valign="top" align="left" style="width: 18.00pt; display: inline;"> <p style="font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt;margin:0pt;"> <sup style="margin:0pt;font-size:10pt;font-family:Times New Roman;;"> (1)</sup> </p> </td><td style="width:0pt;"><p style="width:0pt;width:0pt;font-size:0pt;"></p></td><td align="left" valign="top"> <p style="font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt;margin:0pt;"> <font style="display: inline;font-size:9pt;">The RSUs vested during the three months ended June 30, 2014 and 2013 consisted </font><font style="display: inline;font-size:9pt;">entirely of time-based awards. The RSUs vested during the six months ended June 30, 2014 consisted of </font><font style="display: inline;font-size:9pt;">456,943</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:9pt;"> of time-based awards and </font><font style="display: inline;font-size:9pt;">30,946</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:9pt;"> of performance-based awards.</font><font style="display: inline;">&nbsp;</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:9pt;">The RSUs vested during the six months ended June 30, </font><font style="display: inline;font-size:9pt;background-color:yellow;">2013</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:9pt;"> consisted of </font><font style="display: inline;font-size:9pt;">234,696</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:9pt;"> of time-based awards and </font><font style="display: inline;font-size:9pt;">52,288</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:9pt;"> of performance-based awards.</font></p></td></tr></table></div> <p style="margin:0pt 0pt 0pt 18pt;text-indent: -18pt;line-height:normal;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;">&nbsp;</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt 0pt 0pt 18pt;text-indent: -18pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-weight:bold;font-style:italic;">Appointment of President</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt 0pt 0pt 18pt;text-indent: -18pt;line-height:normal;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;background-color:yellow;">&nbsp;</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;">On May 13, 2014, the board of directors appointed Andrew Rees as President of the Company, effective June 9, 2014.</font><font style="display: inline;">&nbsp;</font><font style="display: inline;">Upon the commencement of his employment, </font><font style="display: inline;">Mr. Rees was granted a market-based RSU with a maximum value of </font><font style="display: inline;">$3.5</font><font style="display: inline;"> million, which shall vest based on the achievement of certain share price levels on or before the fourth anniversary of his start date, subject to continued employment with the Company. </font><font style="display: inline;">This grant represents the right to receive </font><font style="display: inline;">0.2</font><font style="display: inline;"> million shares of the Company&#x2019;s common stock based on the 30-day volume-weighted average price of </font><font style="display: inline;">$15.02</font><font style="display: inline;"> per share immediately prior to his appointment. Based on a Monte-Carlo valuation model, the fair value of the RSU was determined to be </font><font style="display: inline;">$2.3</font><font style="display: inline;"> million, or </font><font style="display: inline;">65.7%</font><font style="display: inline;"> of the grant price, which will be expensed on a straight-line basis over a derived service period of </font><font style="display: inline;">1.788</font><font style="display: inline;"> years.</font> </p> <p><font size="1"> </font></p> </div> </div> 3033000 0.73 0.40 0.26 0.19 0.72 0.40 0.25 0.19 <div> <div style="margin-left:0pt;margin-right:0pt;"> <p style="margin:0pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-weight:bold;font-style:italic;">Earnings per share</font><font style="display: inline;"> - Basic and diluted earnings per common share (&#x201C;EPS&#x201D;) is presented using the two-class method, which is an earnings allocation formula that determines earnings per share for common stock and any participating securities according to dividend rights and participation rights in undistributed earnings. Under the two-class method, EPS is computed by dividing the sum of distributed and undistributed earnings attributable to common stockholders by the weighted average number of shares of common stock outstanding during the period. A participating security is a security that may participate in undistributed earnings with common stock had those earnings been distributed in any form. Our recently issued Series A preferred stock represent participating securities as holders of the Series A preferred stock are entitled to receive any and all dividends declared or paid on common stock on an as-converted basis. In addition, shares of our non-vested restricted stock awards are considered participating securities as they represent unvested share-based payment awards containing non-forfeitable rights to dividends. As such, these participating securities must be included in the computation of EPS pursuant to the two-class method on a pro-rata, as-converted basis. Diluted EPS reflects the potential dilution from securities that could share in our earnings. In addition, the dilutive effect of each participating security is calculated using the more dilutive of the two-class method described above, which assumes that the securities remain in their current form, or the if-converted method, which assumes conversion to common stock as of the beginning of the reporting date. Anti-dilutive securities are excluded from diluted EPS. See </font><font style="display: inline;font-style:italic;">Note 12&#x2014;Earnings Per Share</font><font style="display: inline;"> for further discussion.</font> </p> <p><font size="1"> </font></p> </div> </div> <div> <div style="margin-left:0pt;margin-right:0pt;"> <p style="margin:12pt 0pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-weight:bold;">12</font><font style="display: inline;font-weight:bold;">. EARNINGS PER SHARE</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;">The following table illustrates the basic and diluted </font><font style="display: inline;">EPS</font><font style="display: inline;"> computations for the </font><font style="display: inline;">three and six months</font><font style="display: inline;"> ended </font><font style="display: inline;">June 30, 2014 and 2013:</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt;line-height:normal;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;">&nbsp;</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt;line-height:normal;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 1pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-size:1pt;">&nbsp;</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt;line-height:normal;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 1pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-size:1pt;">&nbsp;</font> </p> <div style="width:100%"><table cellpadding="0" Subject to certain restrictions on repurchases under our revolving credit facility,</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;"> in December 2013, the board of directors authorized the repurchase up to </font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">$350.0</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;"> million of our common stock. </font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">The number, price,</font><font style="display: inline;font-family:Times;font-size:10pt;"> structure and timing of the repurchases, if any, will be at </font><font style="display: inline;font-family:Times;font-size:10pt;">our</font><font style="display: inline;font-family:Times;font-size:10pt;"> sole discretion and future repurchases will be evaluated by </font><font style="display: inline;font-family:Times;font-size:10pt;">us</font><font style="display: inline;font-family:Times;font-size:10pt;"> depending on market conditions, liquidity needs and other factors. Share repurchases may be made in the open market or in privately negotiated transactions. The repurchase authorization does not have an expiration date and does not oblige us to acquire any particular amount of our common stock. The </font><font style="display: inline;font-family:Times;font-size:10pt;">board of directors</font><font style="display: inline;font-family:Times;font-size:10pt;"> may suspend, modify or terminate the repurchase program at any time without prior notice. </font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt;border-top:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-bottom:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> </table></div> <p style="margin:0pt;line-height:normal;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;">&nbsp;</font> </p> <p style="margin:12pt 0pt 6pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-weight:bold;font-style:italic;">Non-Recurring Fair Value Measurements</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">The majority </font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">of our non-financial instrument assets</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">, which include inventories, property and equipment and intangible assets, are not required to be carried at fair value on a recurring basis. However, if certain triggering events occur such that a non-financial instrument is required to be evaluated for impairment and the carrying value is not recoverable, the carrying value would be adjusted to the lower of its cost or fair value and an impai</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">rment charge would be recorded.</font> </p> <p><font size="1"> </font></p> </div> </div> 65633000 4548000 4272000 49665000 6439000 709000 74664000 4539000 4668000 58258000 6563000 636000 24985000 11170000 8679000 10515000 11742000 18281000 137850000 4548000 6501000 118940000 6878000 983000 160036000 4539000 6466000 141497000 6828000 706000 72217000 2229000 69275000 439000 274000 85372000 1798000 83239000 265000 70000 13501000 13501000 984000 984000 -3414000 -814000 -2988000 -220000 -1392000 10892000 23653000 26164000 -10651000 -710000 5208000 3370000 2508000 2479000 <div> <div style="margin-left:0pt;margin-right:0pt;"> <p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-weight:bold;">4. nowrap="nowrap"><div style="float:left"></div>162,341&nbsp; </td> </tr> </table></div> <p style="margin:0pt;line-height:normal;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;">&nbsp;</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt;border-bottom:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-family:Times;font-weight:bold;font-style:italic;font-size:10pt;">Inventory Write-down </font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt;border-top:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 12pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-family:Times;">&nbsp;</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-family:Times;">During the three months ended June 30, 2014, we recorded approxim</font><font style="display: inline;font-family:Times;">ately </font><font style="display: inline;font-family:Times;">$2.0</font><font style="display: inline;font-family:Times;"> million</font><font style="display: inline;font-family:Times;"> of inventory write-down charges related to obsolete inventor</font><font style="display: inline;font-family:Times;">y with a mar</font><font style="display: inline;font-family:Times;">ket value lower than cost. These</font><font style="display: inline;font-family:Times;"> charges were related to certain obsolete footwear in the Other businesses segment an</font><font style="display: inline;font-family:Times;">d are reported in cost of sales in the condensed consolidated statements of income.</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt;line-height:normal;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 1pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-size:1pt;">&nbsp;</font> </p> <p><font size="1"> </font></p> </div> </div> 154272000 184748000 162341000 191648000 7384000 6395000 685000 505000 2029000 823000 517000 880000 403000 93235000 102615000 7200000 7400000 250415000 306689000 875159000 1101873000 186928000 255160000 0 100000000 125000000 3700000 16800000 14400000 11670000 9040000 5100000 5400000 5404000 313000 3374000 5340000 9600000 0 52003000 53582000 -8112000 131131000 -32259000 -31065000 37741000 -16979000 64317000 35356000 32401000 23277000 64317000 35356000 25896000 19523000 4 88069000 25023000 155957000 -9412000 43818000 62788000 24328000 30000 -58506000 50419000 17463000 87810000 -5535000 23005000 35685000 11657000 15000 -31871000 58733000 20330000 139830000 -8345000 38357000 61578000 19565000 30000 -72782000 41911000 13868000 84709000 -4589000 24920000 33895000 12026000 15000 -38224000 9644000 7148000 9684000 7261000 49044000 24776000 55649000 28110000 58378000 31768000 64886000 35128000 310000 156000 447000 243000 <div> <div style="margin-left:0pt;margin-right:0pt;"> <p style="margin:12pt 0pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-weight:bold;">1. GENERAL</font> </p> <p style="margin:12pt 0pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-weight:bold;font-style:italic;">Organization</font> </p> <p style="margin:12pt 0pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;">Crocs,&nbsp;Inc. and its subsidiaries (collectively the &#x201C;Company,&#x201D; &#x201C;we,&#x201D; &#x201C;our&#x201D; or &#x201C;us&#x201D;) are engaged in the design, development, manufacturing, marketing and distribution of footwear, apparel and accessories for men, women and children.</font> </p> <p style="margin:12pt 0pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-weight:bold;font-style:italic;">Basis of Presentation</font> </p> <p style="margin:12pt 0pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;">The accompanying unaudited condensed consolidated financial statements have been prepared in accordance with accounting principles generally accepted in the United States (&#x201C;GAAP&#x201D;) for interim financial information and with the rules&nbsp;and regulations of the Securities and Exchange Commission (&#x201C;SEC&#x201D;) for reporting on Form&nbsp;10-Q. The condensed consolidated balance sheet as of December 31, 2013 was derived from the Company&#x2019;s Annual Report on Form 10-K for the year ended December 31, 2013 (the &#x201C;2013 Form 10-K&#x201D;). Accordingly, these statements do not include all of the information and disclosures required by GAAP or SEC rules&nbsp;and regulations for complete financial statements. In the opinion of management, these financial statements reflect all adjustments (consisting solely of normal recurring matters) considered necessary for a fair presentation of the results for the interim periods presented. The results of operations for any interim period are not necessarily indicative of results for the full year.</font> </p> <p style="margin:12pt 0pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;">In t</font><font style="display: inline;">he accompanying condensed consolidated balance sheet</font><font style="display: inline;">s</font><font style="display: inline;"> as of June 30, 2014, </font><font style="display: inline;">we</font><font style="display: inline;"> recorded an out-of-period adjustment related to the calculation of a beneficial conversion feature associated with the issuance of the Series A </font><font style="display: inline;">convertible </font><font style="display: inline;">preferred stock </font><font style="display: inline;">(&#x201C;Series A preferred stock&#x201D;) on January 27, 2014. </font><font style="display: inline;">This adjustment was a non-cash adjustment and had no effect on operating income. The adjustment decreased the previously reported balance of the Series A preferred stock and increased the previously reported balance of additional paid-i</font><font style="display: inline;">n capital by approximately </font><font style="display: inline;">$12.3</font><font style="display: inline;"> million.&nbsp;The adjustment did not have a material impact on </font><font style="display: inline;">our</font><font style="display: inline;"> condensed consolidated st</font><font style="display: inline;">atements of income for the three </font><font style="display: inline;">months ended March 31, 2014, and there was no impact on </font><font style="display: inline;">our</font><font style="display: inline;"> condensed consolidated statements of comp</font><font style="display: inline;">rehensive income or cash flows for the three </font><font style="display: inline;">months ended March 31, 2014.</font> </p> <p style="margin:12pt 0pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-weight:bold;font-style:italic;">Reclassifications</font> </p> <p style="margin:12pt 0pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;">Certain prior period amounts on the condensed consolidated financial statements have been reclassified to conform to current period presentation. We segregated certain restructuring charges recorded to selling, general and administrative expenses on the condensed consolidated statements of income during the three months ended March 31, 2014 to the restructuring charges line item on the condensed consolidated statements of income during the six months ended June 30, 2014. In addition, we segregated certain accrued restructuring charges recorded to accrued expenses and other liabilities on the condensed consolidated balance sheets at March 31, 2014 and changes in accrued expenses and other liabilities on the condensed consolidated statements of cash flows for the three months ended March 31, 2014 to the accrued restructuring line item on the condensed consolidated balance sheets at June 30, 2014 and changes in accrued restructuring on the condensed consolidated statements of cash flows for the six months ended June 30, 2014. These reclassifications had no effect on income from operations, current liabilities or cash provided by (used in) operating activities.</font> </p> <p style="margin:12pt 0pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-weight:bold;font-style:italic;">Summary of Significant Accounting Policies</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt;border-bottom:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">These statements should be read in conjunction with the consolidated financial statements and footnotes included in the 2013 Form 10-K. The accounting policies used in preparing these unaudited condensed consolidated financial statements are the same as those described in </font><font style="display: inline;font-style:italic;font-size:10pt;">Note 1 &#x2014; Organization &amp; Summary of Significant Accounting Policies</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;"> to the consolidated financial statements in the 2013 Form 10-K.</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt;border-top:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-bottom:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 12pt"> <font style="display: inline;">&nbsp;</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt;border-top:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-weight:bold;font-style:italic;font-size:10pt;">Earnings per share</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;"> - Basic and diluted earnings per common share (&#x201C;EPS&#x201D;) is presented using the two-class method, which is an earnings allocation formula that determines earnings per share for common stock and any participating securities according to dividend rights and participation rights in undistributed earnings. Under the two-class method, EPS is computed by dividing the sum of distributed and undistributed earnings attributable to common stockholders by the weighted average number of shares of common stock outstanding during the period. A participating security is a security that may participate in undistributed earnings with common stock had those earnings been distributed in any form. Our recently issued Series A preferred stock represent participating securities as holders of the Series A preferred stock are entitled to receive any and all dividends declared or paid on common stock on an as-converted basis. In addition, shares of our non-vested restricted stock awards are considered participating securities as they represent unvested share-based payment awards containing non-forfeitable rights to dividends. As such, these participating securities must be included in the computation of EPS pursuant to the two-class method on a pro-rata, as-converted basis. Diluted EPS reflects the potential dilution from securities that could share in our earnings. In addition, the dilutive effect of each participating security is calculated using the more dilutive of the two-class method described above, which assumes that the securities remain in their current form, or the if-converted method, which assumes conversion to common stock as of the beginning of the reporting date. Anti-dilutive securities are excluded from diluted EPS. See </font><font style="display: inline;font-style:italic;font-size:10pt;">Note 12&#x2014;Earnings Per Share</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;"> for further discussion.</font> </p> <p style="margin:12pt 0pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-weight:bold;font-style:italic;">Beneficial conversion feature</font><font style="display: inline;"> &#x2013; The issuance of our Series A preferred stock generated a beneficial conversion feature, which arises when a debt or equity security is issued with an embedded conversion option that is beneficial to the investor or in the money at inception because the conversion option has an effective strike price that is less than the market price of the underlying stock at the commitment date. We recognize</font><font style="display: inline;background-color:yellow;">d the</font><font style="display: inline;"> beneficial conversion feature by allocating the intrinsic value of the conversion option, which is the number of common shares available upon conversion multiplied by the difference between the effective conversion price per share and the fair value of common stock per share on the commitment date, to additional paid-in capital, resulting in a discount on the Series A preferred stock. We will accrete the discount from the date of issuance through the redemption date of eight years following issuance. Accretion expense will be recognized as dividend equivalents over the eight year period utilizing the effective interest method.</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt;border-bottom:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-weight:bold;font-style:italic;font-size:10pt;">Recently Issued Accounting Standards</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt;border-top:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;background-color:yellow;">&nbsp;</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-style:italic;text-decoration:underline;">Discontinued Operations</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt;line-height:normal;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;">&nbsp;</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;">In April 2014, the </font><font style="display: inline;">Financial Accounting Standards Board (&#x201C;FASB&#x201D;) </font><font style="display: inline;">issued Accounting Standards Update (&#x201C;ASU&#x201D;) No. 2014-08: </font><font style="font-style:italic;display: inline;">Presentation of Financial Statements (Topic 205) and Property, Plant, and Equipment (Topic 360): Reporting Discontinued Operations and Disclosures of Disposals of Components of an Entity</font><font style="display: inline;">, which amends the definition of a discontinued operation in ASC 205-20 and requires entities to provide additional disclosures about discontinued operations as well as disposal transactions that do not meet the discontinued-operations criteria. The FASB issued the ASU to provide more decision-useful information and to make it more difficult for a disposal transaction to qualify as a discontinued operation. Under the previous guidance, the results of operations of a component of an entity were classified as a discontinued operation if all of the following conditions were met:</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt;line-height:normal;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;">&nbsp;</font> </p> <div style="width:100%"><table style="width:100%;" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0"><tr><td style="width:18pt;"><p style="width:18pt;font-size:0pt;"></p></td><td valign="top" align="left" style="width: 18.00pt; display: inline;"> <p style="border-bottom:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt;margin:0pt;"> <font style="margin:0pt;font-family:Symbol;border-bottom:1pt none #D9D9D9;font-size:10pt;;"> &#xB7;</font> </p> </td><td style="width:0pt;"><p style="width:0pt;width:0pt;font-size:0pt;"></p></td><td align="left" valign="top"> <p style="border-bottom:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt;margin:0pt;"> <font style="display: inline;">The component has been disposed of or is classified as held for sale.</font></p></td></tr></table></div> <div style="width:100%"><table style="width:100%;" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0"><tr><td style="width:18pt;"><p style="width:18pt;font-size:0pt;"></p></td><td valign="top" align="left" style="width: 18.00pt; display: inline;"> <p style="border-top:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-bottom:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt;margin:0pt;"> <font style="margin:0pt;font-family:Symbol;border-top:1pt none #D9D9D9;border-bottom:1pt none #D9D9D9;font-size:10pt;;"> &#xB7;</font> </p> </td><td style="width:0pt;"><p style="width:0pt;width:0pt;font-size:0pt;"></p></td><td align="left" valign="top"> <p style="border-top:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-bottom:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt;margin:0pt;"> <font style="display: inline;">The operations and cash flows of the component have been (or will be) eliminated from the ongoing operations of the entity as a result of the disposal transaction.</font></p></td></tr></table></div> <div style="width:100%"><table style="width:100%;" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0"><tr><td style="width:18pt;"><p style="width:18pt;font-size:0pt;"></p></td><td valign="top" align="left" style="width: 18.00pt; display: inline;"> <p style="border-top:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt;margin:0pt;"> <font style="margin:0pt;font-family:Symbol;border-top:1pt none #D9D9D9;font-size:10pt;;"> &#xB7;</font> </p> </td><td style="width:0pt;"><p style="width:0pt;width:0pt;font-size:0pt;"></p></td><td align="left" valign="top"> <p style="border-top:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt;margin:0pt;"> <font style="display: inline;">The entity will not have any significant continuing involvement in the operations of the component after the disposal transaction.</font></p></td></tr></table></div> <p style="margin:0pt;line-height:normal;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;">&nbsp;</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;">The new guidance eliminates the second and third criteria above and instead requires discontinued o</font><font style="display: inline;">perations treatment for disposal</font><font style="display: inline;">s of a component or group of components that represents a strategic shift that has or will have a major impact on an entity&#x2019;s operations or financial results. The ASU also expands the scope of ASC 205-20 to disposals of equity method investments and businesses that, upon initial acquisition, qualify as held for sale. </font><font style="display: inline;">In addition, the ASU requires entities to reclassify assets and liabilities of a discontinued operation for all comparative periods presented in the statement of financial position. Before these amendments, ASC 205-20 neither required nor prohibited such presentation.</font><font style="display: inline;">&nbsp;</font><font style="display: inline;">Regarding the statement of cash flows, an entity must disclose, in all periods presented, either (1) operating and investing cash flows or (2) depreciation and amortization, capital expenditures, and significant operating and investing noncash items related to the discontinued operation. This presentation requirement represents a significant change from previous guidance. This ASU is effective prospectively for all disposals or components initially classified as held for sale in periods beginning on or after December 15, 2014. </font><font style="display: inline;">Early adoption is permitted. </font><font style="display: inline;">The Company does not anticipate this pronouncement to have a material impact to the Company&#x2019;s consolidated financial </font><font style="display: inline;">statements</font><font style="display: inline;">.</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt;line-height:normal;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;">&nbsp;</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt;border-bottom:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-style:italic;font-size:10pt;text-decoration:underline;">Revenue Recognition</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt;border-top:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">&nbsp;</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;">In May 2014, the FASB issued their final standard on revenue from contracts with customers. The standard, issued as ASU No. 2014-09: </font><font style="display: inline;font-style:italic;">Revenue from Contracts with Customers</font><font style="display: inline;font-style:italic;">&nbsp;</font><font style="display: inline;font-style:italic;">(Topic 606)</font><font style="display: inline;">&nbsp;</font><font style="display: inline;">by the FASB, outlines a single comprehensive model for entities to use in accounting for revenue arising from contracts with customers and supersedes most current revenue recognition guidance, including industry-specific guidance. The core principle of the revenue model is that &#x201C;an entity recognizes revenue to depict the transfer of promised goods or services to customers in an amount that reflects the consideration to which the entity expects to be entitled in exchange for those goods or services.&#x201D; In applying the revenue model to contracts within its scope, an entity:</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt;line-height:normal;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;">&nbsp;</font> </p> <div style="width:100%"><table style="width:100%;" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0"><tr><td style="width:18pt;"><p style="width:18pt;font-size:0pt;"></p></td><td valign="top" align="left" style="width: 18.00pt; display: inline;"> <p style="border-bottom:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt;margin:0pt;"> <font style="margin:0pt;font-family:Symbol;border-bottom:1pt none #D9D9D9;font-size:10pt;;"> &#xB7;</font> </p> </td><td style="width:0pt;"><p style="width:0pt;width:0pt;font-size:0pt;"></p></td><td align="left" valign="top"> <p style="border-bottom:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt;margin:0pt;"> <font style="display: inline;">Identifies the contr</font><font style="display: inline;">act(s) with a customer (Step 1)</font></p></td></tr></table></div> <div style="width:100%"><table style="width:100%;" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0"><tr><td style="width:18pt;"><p style="width:18pt;font-size:0pt;"></p></td><td valign="top" align="left" style="width: 18.00pt; display: inline;"> <p style="border-top:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-bottom:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt;margin:0pt;"> <font style="margin:0pt;font-family:Symbol;border-top:1pt none #D9D9D9;border-bottom:1pt none #D9D9D9;font-size:10pt;;"> &#xB7;</font> </p> </td><td style="width:0pt;"><p style="width:0pt;width:0pt;font-size:0pt;"></p></td><td align="left" valign="top"> <p style="border-top:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-bottom:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt;margin:0pt;"> <font style="display: inline;">Identifies the performance oblig</font><font style="display: inline;">ations in the contract (Step 2)</font></p></td></tr></table></div> <div style="width:100%"><table style="width:100%;" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0"><tr><td style="width:18pt;"><p style="width:18pt;font-size:0pt;"></p></td><td valign="top" align="left" style="width: 18.00pt; display: inline;"> <p style="border-top:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-bottom:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt;margin:0pt;"> <font style="margin:0pt;font-family:Symbol;border-top:1pt none #D9D9D9;border-bottom:1pt none #D9D9D9;font-size:10pt;;"> &#xB7;</font> </p> </td><td style="width:0pt;"><p style="width:0pt;width:0pt;font-size:0pt;"></p></td><td align="left" valign="top"> <p style="border-top:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-bottom:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt;margin:0pt;"> <font style="display: inline;">Determines</font><font style="display: inline;"> the transaction price (Step 3)</font></p></td></tr></table></div> <div style="width:100%"><table style="width:100%;" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0"><tr><td style="width:18pt;"><p style="width:18pt;font-size:0pt;"></p></td><td valign="top" align="left" style="width: 18.00pt; display: inline;"> <p style="border-top:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-bottom:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt;margin:0pt;"> <font style="margin:0pt;font-family:Symbol;border-top:1pt none #D9D9D9;border-bottom:1pt none #D9D9D9;font-size:10pt;;"> &#xB7;</font> </p> </td><td style="width:0pt;"><p style="width:0pt;width:0pt;font-size:0pt;"></p></td><td align="left" valign="top"> <p style="border-top:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-bottom:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt;margin:0pt;"> <font style="display: inline;">Allocates the transaction price to the performance oblig</font><font style="display: inline;">ations in the contract (Step 4)</font></p></td></tr></table></div> <div style="width:100%"><table style="width:100%;" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0"><tr><td style="width:18pt;"><p style="width:18pt;font-size:0pt;"></p></td><td valign="top" align="left" style="width: 18.00pt; display: inline;"> <p style="border-top:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt;margin:0pt;"> <font style="margin:0pt;font-family:Symbol;border-top:1pt none #D9D9D9;font-size:10pt;;"> &#xB7;</font> </p> </td><td style="width:0pt;"><p style="width:0pt;width:0pt;font-size:0pt;"></p></td><td align="left" valign="top"> <p style="border-top:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt;margin:0pt;"> <font style="display: inline;">Recognizes revenue when (or as) the entity satisfies a perfor</font><font style="display: inline;">mance obligation (Step 5)</font></p></td></tr></table></div> <p style="margin:0pt;line-height:normal;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;">&nbsp;</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;">The ASU applies to all contracts with customers except those that are within the scope of other topics in the FASB Accounting Standards Codification. Certain of the ASU&#x2019;s provisions also apply to transfers of nonfinancial assets, including in-substance nonfinancial assets that are not an output of an entity&#x2019;s ordinary</font><font style="display: inline;"> activities (e.g., sales of </font><font style="display: inline;">prop</font><font style="display: inline;">erty, plant, and equipment, real estate or </font><font style="display: inline;">intangible assets).</font><font style="display: inline;">&nbsp;</font><font style="display: inline;">Existing accounting guidan</font><font style="display: inline;">ce applicable to these transfers </font><font style="display: inline;">has been amended or superseded. Compared with current U.S. GAAP, the ASU also requires significantly expanded disclosures about revenue recognition.</font><font style="display: inline;">&nbsp;</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt;border-bottom:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;background-color:yellow;">&nbsp;</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt;border-top:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">T</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">he ASU is effective for annual reporting periods (including interim reporting periods within those periods) beginning after December 15, 2016. Early application is not permitted</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">. &nbsp;</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">The Company </font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">is currently evaluating the impact that this pronouncement will have on </font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">the Company&#x2019;s consolidated financial </font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">statements</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">.</font> </p> <p><font size="1"> </font></p> </div> </div> 6513000 6475000 53661000 40983000 -3000 0 0 0 10567000 6250000 759000 -221000 15201000 16745000 -733000 -732000 -167000 -195000 171000 30000 679000 619000 243000 127000 3543000 2683000 12533000 47005000 -1922000 -403000 -1410000 -109000 2134000 0 15800000 256000 787000 11833000 18944000 19676000 11376000 5166000 3033000 0.001 0.001 5000000 5000000 0 0 29175000 37923000 1439000 1209000 182220000 14572000 545000 43000 <div> <div style="margin-left:0pt;margin-right:0pt;"> <p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-weight:bold;">3. style="display: inline;font-weight:bold;">6. RESTRUCTURING ACTIVITIES</font> </p> <p style="margin:4.5pt 0pt 0pt;border-bottom:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-weight:bold;font-style:italic;font-size:10pt;">Restructuring</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt;border-top:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-bottom:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;background-color:yellow;">&nbsp;</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt;border-top:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-bottom:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">On July 21, 2014, we announced strategic plans for long-term improv</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">ement and growth of the business. </font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">These plans comprise four</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;"> key initiatives including: (1) s</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">treamlining the global product and marketing portfolio, (2) reducing direct investment in smaller geographic markets, (3) creating a more efficient organizational structure including reducing duplicative and excess overhead which will also enhance the decision making process, and (4) closing or converting approx</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">imately </font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">75</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;"> to </font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">100</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;"> retail location</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">s around the world.</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;"> The initial effects of these plans were incurred in the first and second quarter of 2014 and are expected to continue for the next 18 months. </font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">As a result, the Company recorded restructuring charges of $4.1 million and $6.3 million during the three and six months ended June 30, 2014, respectively. We are </font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">unable in good faith to determine the type of cost</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">s &nbsp;</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;background-color:yellow;">we</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;"> will incur in connection with this </font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">strategic restructuring </font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">plan or to estimate the total amount or range of amounts expected to be incurred in connection with this plan for each major type of cost associated with this </font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">strategic restructuring plan.</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt;border-top:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-bottom:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">&nbsp;</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt;border-top:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-bottom:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">The following table summarized our restructuring activity during the three and six months ended June 30, 2014:</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt;border-top:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-bottom:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: align="left"></hr> <p style="margin:0pt 0pt 0pt 18pt;text-indent: -18pt;line-height:normal;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 3pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-size:3pt;">&nbsp;</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt 0pt 0pt 18pt;text-indent: -18pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-size:9pt;font-size:5pt;top:-4pt;position:relative;line-height:100%">(1)</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:9pt;font-size:5pt;top:-4pt;position:relative;line-height:100%;font-size: 10pt;font-family:Times New Roman;text-indent:0pt;margin-left:0pt;padding:0pt 9.9pt 0pt 0pt;"></font><font style="display: inline;font-size:9pt;font-size:5pt;top:-4pt;position:relative;line-height:100%"></font><font style="display: inline;font-size:9pt;">Adjustments relate to differences resulting from the translation of the liability balance at the balance sheet rate and restructuring expense translated at the weighted-average rate of exchange for the applicable period.</font> </p> <p style="margin:12pt 0pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-weight:bold;font-style:italic;">Retail Store Closings</font> </p> <p style="margin:4.5pt 0pt 0pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">As mentioned above, the Company plans to close 75 to 100 retail locations around the globe. As such, we expect to incur certain exit costs specific to store closures including operating lease termination costs, rent obligations for leased facilities, net of expected sublease income, and other expenses in association with this plan. </font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">During the three and six months ended June 30, 2014, we closed seven and nine </font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">company-operated </font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">retail locations, respectively, which were not scheduled to close until future periods and were selected for closure by management based on historical and projected profitability levels, relocation plans, and other factor</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">s. As of June 30, 2014, we recorded a liability of approxi</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">mately </font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">$0.5</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;"> million re</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">lated to these locations in accrued restructuring on the condensed consolidated balance sh</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">eets. </font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">The calculation of accrued store closing reserves primarily includes future minimum lease payments from the date of closure to the end of the remaining lease term, net of contractual or estimated sublease income. We record the liability at fair value in the period in which the store is closed.</font> </p> <p><font size="1"> </font></p> </div> </div> 6310000 5761000 1224000 393000 1162000 4451000 982000 3711000 </div> <div> <div style="margin-left:0pt;margin-right:0pt;"> <p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-weight:bold;">15</font><font style="display: inline;font-weight:bold;">. OPERATING SEGMENTS &amp; GEOGRAPHIC INFORMATION</font> </p> <p style="margin:12pt 0pt;border-bottom:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">W</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">e have </font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">four</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;"> reportable operating segments</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;"> based on the geographic nature of our operations</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">: Americas,</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;"> Asia Pacific, Japan and Europe. </font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">We also have an &#x201C;Other businesses&#x201D; category which aggregates insignificant operating segments that do not meet the reportable threshold and represent manufacturing o</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">perations located in Mexico, </font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">Italy</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;"> and Asia. </font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">The composition of our reportable operating segments is consistent with that used by our </font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">Chief Operating Decision Maker (&#x201C;CODM&#x201D;)</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;"> to evaluate performance and allocate resources.</font> </p> <p style="margin:12pt 0pt;border-top:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-bottom:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">Each of our reportable operating segments derives its revenues from the sale of footwear, apparel and accessories to external customers</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;"> as well as intersegment sales</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">. Revenues of the &#x201C;Other businesses&#x201D; category are primaril</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">y made up of intersegment sales</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">. The remaining revenues for the &#x201C;Other businesses&#x201D; represent non-footwear produ</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">ct sales to external customers. Intersegment sales are not included in the measurement of segment operating income or regularly reviewed by the CODM and are eliminated when deriving total consolidated revenues.</font> </p> <p style="margin:12pt 0pt;border-top:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 12pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">The primary </font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">financial </font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">measure utilized by the CODM to evaluate performance and allocate resources is segment operating income. Segment performance evaluation is based primarily on segment results without allocating corporate expenses, or indirect general, ad</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">ministrative and other expenses. Segment profits or losses of our reportable operating segments include adjustments to eliminate intersegment profit or losses on intersegment sales. </font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">As such, reconciling items for segment operating income represent unallocated corporate and other expenses as well as intersegment eliminations. </font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">Segment assets consist of cash and cash equivalents, accounts receivable and inventory</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;"> as these balances are regularly reviewed by the CODM</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">.</font> </p> <p><font size="1"> </font></p><p style="page-break-after:always">&nbsp;</p> <p style="margin:12pt 0pt;border-top:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;font-family:Times New Roman;;font-size: 12pt"><font style="display: inline;"></font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;">The following table sets forth information related to our reportable operating business segments during the three</font><font style="display: inline;"> and six</font><font style="display: inline;"> months ended </font><font style="display: inline;">June 30, 2014 and 2013</font><font style="display: inline;">:</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt;line-height:normal;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 1pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-size:1pt;">&nbsp;</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 1pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-size:1pt;">&nbsp;</font> </p> <div style="width:100%"><table cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="border-collapse:collapse;width: SUBSEQUENT EVENTS</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt;border-top:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-bottom:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-weight:bold;font-size:10pt;">&nbsp;</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt;border-top:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;background-color: #FFFFFF;">On July&nbsp;21, 2014, after a comprehensive strategic review of the Company&#x2019;s business and operations globally, the Company announced a strategic plan for long-term improvement and growth of its business.&nbsp;&nbsp;Under the plan, the Company expects, among other things, to (i) s</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">treamline its product portfolio, eliminate non-core product development and explore strategic alternatives for non-core brands, (ii) reorganize key business functions to improve efficiency and eliminate </font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">183</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;"> global positions and (iii) close or convert approximately </font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">75</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;"> to </font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">100</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;"> Crocs branded retail stores around the world.</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;background-color: #FFFFFF;"> &nbsp;The actions associated with the plan are expected to be completed </font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;background-color: #FFFFFF;">in the next 18 months</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;background-color: #FFFFFF;">.</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;background-color: #FFFFFF;"> Pursuant to the announcement, on July 21, 2014, the Company incurred severance charges of approximately </font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;background-color: #FFFFFF;">$2.9</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;background-color: #FFFFFF;"> million related to the termination of certain employees.</font> </p> <p><font size="1"> </font></p> </div> </div> 1339000 721000 171282000 0.001 0.001 203000000 3212453 6409161 55964000 102270000 31600000 23000000 88768000 88837 88873000 87799 87823000 87865 87559000 86887 Includes $0.1 million and $0.1 million of accumulated depreciation related to certain equipment held under capital leases as of June 30, 2014 and December 31, 2013, respectively, which are depreciated using the straight-line method over the lease term. Corporate assets primarily consist of cash and equivalents which increased predominately due to net cash proceeds from our investment with Blackstone. See Note 13 - Series A Preferred Stock for further details regarding the preferred share offering. Includes a corporate component consisting primarily of corporate support and administrative functions, costs associated with share-based compensation, research and development, brand marketing, legal, depreciation and amortization of corporate and other assets not allocated to operating segments and costs of the same nature related to certain corporate holding companies. Includes $2.2 million and $1.9 million of accumulated amortization of software held under a capital lease as of June 30, 2014 and December 31, 2013, respectively, which is amortized using the straight-line method over the useful life. Includes $4.1 million of software held under a capital lease classified as capitalized software as of June 30, 2014 and December 31, 2013. Minimum rentals include all lease payments as well as fixed and variable common area maintenance (“CAM”), parking and storage fees, which were approximately $2.5 million during the three months ended June 30, 2014 and 2013, respectively, and $4.9 million during the six months ended June 30, 2014 and 2013, respectively. The amounts in ‘Other’ consist of various accrued expenses and no individual item accounted for more than 5% of the total balance at June 30, 2014 or December 31, 2013. The amounts in ‘Other’ consist of various asset impairment charges prompted by the aforementioned restructuring plan, legal fees and facility maintenance fees. Includes $0.1 million and $0.1 million of certain equipment held under capital leases and classified as equipment as of June 30, 2014 and December 31, 2013, respectively. Adjustments relate to differences resulting from the translation of the liability balance at the balance sheet rate and restructuring expense translated at the weighted-average rate of exchange for the applicable period. The RSAs vested during the three and six months ended June 30, 2014 and 2013 consisted entirely of time-based awards. The RSUs vested during the three months ended June 30, 2014 and 2013 consisted entirely of time-based awards. The RSUs vested during the six months ended June 30, 2014 consisted of 456,943 of time-based awards and 30,946 of performance-based awards. The RSUs vested during the six months ended June 30, 2013 consisted of 234,696 of time-based awards and 52,288 of performance-based awards. Total liabilities and stockholders' equity Allowance for doubtful accounts related to trade receivables and reserves for sales returns. Allowances for Doubtful Accounts and Reserve for Sales Returns and Allowances Allowances TemporaryEquityParOrStatedValuePerShare Series A preferred shares, par value The number of securities classified as temporary equity that have been sold (or granted) to the entity's shareholders and are held by the entity's shareholders. Securities issued include securities outstanding and securities held in treasury. Securities outstanding equals securities issued minus securities held in treasury. Series A preferred shares, issued and outstanding Temporary equity redemption value and liquidation preference. The aggregate amount to be paid by the entity upon redemption of the security that is classified as temporary equity. The aggregate liquidation preference (or restrictions) of stock classified as temporary equity that has a preference in involuntary liquidation considerably in excess of the par or stated value of the shares. The liquidation preference is the difference between the preference in liquidation and the par or stated values of the share. An entity discloses certain information on each reportable segment if the amounts (a) are included in the measure of segment profit or loss reviewed by the chief operating decision maker or (b) are otherwise regularly provided to the chief operating decision maker, even if not included in that measure of segment profit or loss. Maximum number of stores to be closed SeveranceCosts1 Severance costs BusinessExitCosts1 Lease / contract exit and related costs OtherRestructuringCosts Other Material Reconciling Items [Member] Significant Reconciling Items [Member] Restructuring Reserve Accrued restructuring as of June 30, 2014 Accrued restructuring as of December 31, 2013 Payments for Restructuring Cash payments Restructuring Reserve, Translation Adjustment Adjustments Accrued liability related to store closures Accrued liability related to store closures Fair Value Measurements, Recurring and Nonrecurring [Table] Fair Value, Assets and Liabilities Measured on Recurring Basis [Table] Fair Value, Hierarchy [Axis] Fair Value Measurements Fair Value Hierarchy [Domain] Fair Value, Measurements, Fair Value Hierarchy [Domain] Fair Value Inputs Level1 [Member] Level 1 [Member] Fair Value Inputs Level2 [Member] Level 2 [Member] Fair Value Inputs Level3 [Member] Level 3 [Member] Fair Value, Assets and Liabilities Measured on Recurring Basis Fair Value, Assets and Liabilities Measured on Recurring Basis [Line Items] Cash equivalents, excluding items classified as marketable securities, include short-term, highly liquid investments that are both readily convertible to known amounts of cash, and so near their maturity that they present minimal risk of changes in value because of changes in interest rates. Generally, only investments with original maturities of three months or less qualify under that definition. Original maturity means original maturity to the entity holding the investment. For example, both a three-month US Treasury bill and a three-year Treasury note purchased three months from maturity qualify as cash equivalents. However, a Treasury note purchased three years ago does not become a cash equivalent when its remaining maturity is three months. xbrli:sharesItemType Balance Type: na Period Type: duration X - Definition This element represents the weighted average total number of shares issued throughout the period including the first (beginning balance outstanding) and last (ending balance outstanding) day of the period before considering any reductions (for instance, shares held in treasury) to arrive at the weighted average number of shares outstanding. Weighted average relates to the portion of time within a reporting period that common shares have been issued and outstanding to the total time in that period. Such concept is used in determining the weighted average number of shares outstanding for purposes of calculating earnings per share (basic). + References Reference 1:
